Steps to reproduce
------------------
cat $PROFILE
```powershell
Function Prompt
{
	Write-Host	
	Write-Host "$($executionContext.SessionState.Path.CurrentLocation)" -ForegroundColor Green	
	"PS> "
}
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
In WindowsPowerShell, it works fine as below:
```powershell
C:\Users\chenyj
PS>
```

Actual behavior
---------------
But in pwsh, it shows the prompt twice as below:
```powershell
/root
PS> 
/root
PS>   
```

---------------
cat /etc/redhat-release
```powershell
CentOS Linux release 7.4.1708 (Core) 
```

comments.body: @chenyj796 Please include the output of `$PSVersionTable` in the issue as per the template so we know what version/platform you are running on. I tried your example - it doesn't repro with 6.1.0-preview.2 on Windows but it does repro on (Ubuntu) Linux.

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
I don't see anything wrong with the prompt code.  And I see the same results in any version of Powershell.

![prompt_code_1_2018-06-13_12-21-37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/41364455-c4b39800-6f04-11e8-98c7-23476e1257c1.jpg)


I use the following Prompt code with the $host.UI.RawUI.CursorPosition with the $pwd variable to get the nice clean prompt. And, every time I clear the host, it shows the folder at the top. 

```
function prompt
{
	## - This function will change the PS Console to enumerate each line preventing long pathnames:
	if ($host.UI.RawUI.CursorPosition.Y -eq 0) {
		"< $pwd > `n`r" + "PS [1] > "
	}
	Else {
		"PS [" + $host.UI.RawUI.CursorPosition.Y + "] > "
	}
};
```
Works in any PowerShell version!
![prompt_code_2018-06-13_12-21-37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/41364364-6e5227a6-6f04-11e8-9551-3dc1829ba7f6.jpg)

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body: @chenyj796 The preview.3 release was out, and I have verified that the prompt works as expected on Linux (Ubuntu 16.04). Please install the preview.3 powershell core (`apt-get update`, then `apt-get install -y powershell-preview`), and then start it with `pwsh-preview` (yes, we renamed the symlink for preview powershell starting from this release to enable stable/preview side-by-side).
